reviews.review_msg: If you skip a class, god bless you. Doesn't use slides or have notes. Amazing lectures but stressful to take notes in. LOTS of reading, 4-5 PhD level novels are assigned. You'll honestly be there for only 2/3 of the class because he's always late, ends early, and takes long breaks. Writing centric but easy-ish marker. Easy to ask questions.

ATTEND CLASS AND RECORD HIS LECTURES. He's not for everyone, as he's VERY lecture heavy without any visuals, but his lectures are very interesting. Take good notes, do your readings, and participate in seminar/tutorial. He is intimidating and a tough grader, but marks fairly if you support your points well based off readings, lectures, and research

Stuart is an amazing orator, but his teaching style is definitely not for everyone. If you are a visual learner and have difficulty following classes that are lecture heavy, you will find his classes difficult. That being said, if you are a good note-taker, you participate, and go to see him outside of class, you will do well and get good grades.

RECORD LECTURES. Don't ask him, just do it. Don't distribute (because then it's illegal). It will help SO MUCH. He may seem unorganized, but his lectures are actually very interesting and it all connects in the end once you have the pieces to connect it :) good luck fams

Lectures were so disorganized and all over the place. He doesn't have any visual aids so good luck trying to stay focused for 3 hours of him just talking. His grading for papers are so high and doesn't give clear criteria for them either. Overall really really disliked this course so good luck to anyone whoever is taking his courses.
His lecture is so confusing and disorganized. I wasn't able to keep up his lecture as well as his high demanding in writing academic essays
Worst prof. ever

This class was the worst one I took so far... and Im in my last year. He would lecture with no visual aids (power points, pictures, etc) which are all often used in history. None of our assignments were handed out -ever... and of course, we never received feedback (including in-class discussions).

The most unorthodox professor I've had the pleasure of learning under. He is extremely knowledgeable on various historical subjects and concepts. His style of teaching is engaging and rewarding. A lot of weekly readings, but if you manage your time well, you won't have a problem.

While I think he's a really interesting guy the class was horrible. It was cross referenced as an IS class so maybe that was part of why I found it so weird. He doesn't use visual aids, I had to complain to the department to get a response to my emails and it's the last week of school and I haven't recieved any assignments back. Do not recommend.

Fantastic orator. Lectures are interesting; packed with information imparted by hard facts and amusing anecdotes. I see some complaints here saying he's all over the place in lecture -- to this I say pay attention and you'll have a great experience. Everything he says in the narrative is intersectional, although it may not always be obvious.

Professor Parker is an excellent professor. His lecturers may appear abstract or arbitrary, but he has a way of ingraining his points in them. Do the readings, like others have said 3 hrs/week. Tests were mix of ID questions (10 terms, chose 5 to answer) and Essay (multiple prompts, answer 1). Class is easy if you show up to lectures + do readings

He doesn't use textbook or powerpoint at all. His lecture is all over the place, no linkage between topics. if you are in his tutorial, you have to read all the assigned articles posted otherwise you will get a zero in attendance. He doesn't hold up to his office hours, never replies emails. Knowledgable guy but bad teacher.

Stuart Parker is a phenomenal lecturer and has extensive knowledge on the course concepts. He is very inspirational and provides a scathing view of history from a leftist political standpoint. He doesn't use slides and teaches the course like he is telling a story. It is easy to follow, but makes you attend class and participate in learning.

Not sure why my review was removed but this prof is terrible. Youre required to participate in class but its pretty apparent than he only wants participation that supports his questionable interpretation of material. Hes late for class and disorganized. Avoid like the plague.

Stuart was very interested in what he was teaching and had a lot of useful information, however, his lectures were all over the place. If you are in his tutorials, make sure you do the readings and are ready to talk, because showing up alone is not enough to get a decent grade. He also marks tough but gives useful advice on where you can improve.

Stuart Parker is one of the worst lecturers in the department. Often times, he will go off  topic and says some really bizarre things that may be untrue. The lectures also do not relate well to the readings. It is a waste of time as you don't  learn anything from him. H doesnt use powerpoint or any notes & so it's hard to tell what is important

Stuart is an awesome lecturer who can keep students engaged without using powerpoint. He was somewhat disorganized (was often late to class, lost sign up sheets, etc) but the course content was interesting. I heard he is a tough marker, so don't enrol in his tutorials.

Stuart is a prof that you either love or really don't enjoy. Personally I find his lectures very confusing because he goes off on strange tangents and never uses power points or notes (I sometimes question if what he's saying is true). The amount of reading is tolerable, but he is a very hard marker and never attends his office hours.
Stuart is quirky but super knowledgeable. He doesn't use PowerPoint slides so get ready to be there every class to take notes. He also assigns a lot  of reading, especially for a second year class.
Fantastic lecturer and a knowledgeable academic. I would highly recommend this class to anybody looking to expand their knowledge of economics in a historical context.

So by the end of the course, I had entirely changed my perspective of Stuart.  His lectures seem long and confusing, but going back and looking at your notes you can see clear, unifying themes.  I was surprised at how much of the material stuck, and how much I learnt.  This class pushed me hard and I believe Stuart has made me a better student.

Stuart Parker has lost the entire classes papers, perhaps on a train, but more likely has forgotten to mark them.  EXTREMELY knowledgeable on the subject, so questions will likely be answered, but is too all over the place to be at all helpful in preparing for the final exam.  If you take this class, best of luck.  I pray for your dear, dear soul.

Parker is a good lecturer, really makes you listen to what he is saying. But readings were far to heavy for a 200 level course (100-150 pages per week). Participation is very important, if you don't talk in tutorial you will not get a good mark. I received limited feedback throughout the course on how to improve my assignments.

Super laid-back, but often late to class . Depended on online responses and the weekly tutorial gave needed insight. Two 4-6 page papers and a 3-hour final exam. Had a slightly difficult time adjusting to the amount of reading as this is a second-year course and I'd taken it as first year. Keep up with the readings and it's straightforward

I have him for IS 220 and IS209W - and he really inspires me. Entertaining to listen to and makes you want to read the articles he assigns. He does not use PP or any supplements in lectures, so get ready for taking a lot of notes. Read the articles, participate in class, use simple language in your essays and you'll be fine.
he doesnt post slides so be there in class evryweek

Stuart Parker: a debonair gentleman of dashing charm. His intellect and wit kept me perched on the edge of my seat. Insightful as only a person of his experienced and studied wisdom can be, I can recommend no other professor so highly.

Great prof, very intelligent guy with broad interests. Course was on the History of the Indian Ocean, so mostly about East Africa, Arabia and India. Kind of an interdisciplinary feel to his approach. You will have to do the readings. He has a slight fondness for amusing crackpot theories.

Great Prof. though sometimes hard to follow, no slides - old school style of lecture, very demanding course and readings can be extremely hard, insightful class and very interesting approach to wealth and poverty of nations, must not be shy to ask questions! :) Great course if you like challenges!

This prof may not use slides but he shares perspectives that will broaden your horizons considerably. Do not miss lectures and take notes. Very insightful on all the subtopics. A significant amount of reading but all foundational stuff.

While the course is supposed to be about the wealth and poverty of nations, this prof made it more about American history and international exchange students... On the final exam we didn't even talk about the Greek financial crisis, which was supposed to be the big topic we'd learn in this course. He's unorganized and rude. I wouldn't recommend him

While he is interesting, and he brings in some unique point of views in lecture, he doesn't use any slides, doesn't send out lecture materials, and didn't connect the textbook and lecture  at all until about half way through the course. He does like to challenge students though, but he doesn't do an amazing job of teaching us in the first place....
